docs.lead_paragraph: Her attention now fixed on Washington, Gov. Christie Whitman offered a rosy recollection of her seven years in office and presented only a few new initiatives today, in what is likely to be her last annual address to the Legislature. In a carefully staged farewell performance in Trenton's ornate War Memorial auditorium, complete with a lengthy videotape showing Mrs. Whitman canoeing, kissing animals and trumpeting her many tax cuts, the governor claimed credit for creating hundreds of thousands of jobs, slashing New Jersey's welfare rolls in half, cutting crime and lifting children out of poverty since taking office in 1994.

headline.main: With Eye to D.C., Whitman Gives Rosy Valedictory On Her Tenure

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-10 Bosnian Serb Ex-Leader To Meet With Tribunal Biljana Plavsic, 70, the former president of the Bosnian Serb republic, was reported to have flown to the Hague to cooperate with the United Nations war crimes tribunal for the countries that once made up Yugoslavia. But it was unclear if she would be treated as a defendant or as a witness. A10

docs.lead_paragraph: Extendicare Inc., an operator of nursing homes in the United States and Canada, said it would pull out of the Florida market because of rising insurance costs. The company said it sold one home in Tampa to a buyer it did not name for $3.7 million, and had leased 15 Florida properties to Tandem Health Care or Senior Health Properties-South. Extendicare, based in Markham, Ontario, got about one-seventh of its revenue of $896 million from its Florida operations in the first nine months of 2000, but the properties lost money.

headline.main: NURSING HOME OPERATOR CLOSES ITS FLORIDA BUSINESS

docs.lead_paragraph: The Public Lives profile on Monday, about the Clinton administration's top drug policy official, Gen. Barry R. McCaffrey, who advocates health insurance coverage for addiction and mental illness on a par with benefits for physical illness, referred incorrectly to the group that has just received such benefits under the federal employee plan. The nine million insured are not all current federal employees; they include dependents and retirees.
docs.abstract: Correction of Public Lives profile on Jan 8 about drug official Gen Barry R McCaffrey, who advocates health insurance coverage for addiction and mental illness on par with benefits for physical illness; nine million insured who now have benefits are federal employees and their families and retirees

docs.lead_paragraph: A Manhattan obstetrician with a celebrity clientele was convicted yesterday of defrauding insurance companies to have them pay for expensive fertility procedures, a case that was closely watched by doctors and their patients in the booming fertility industry. The doctor, Niels H. Lauersen, was convicted of something that many in his profession have quietly done for years: billing insurance companies for covered gynecological procedures to mask the uncovered fertility procedures he was performing.

headline.main: Doctor Convicted of Insurance Fraud in Fertility Procedures

docs.abstract: Dr Niels H Lauersen, Manhattan obstetrician with celebrity clientele, is convicted of defrauding insurance companies to have them pay for expensive fertility procedures, case that was closely watched by doctors and their patients in booming fertility industry; many experts expect outcome to set template for future cases and perhaps even policy regarding fertility treatments, costly procedures that are rarely covered by health insurance policies, something women have challenged in courts; photo (M)

byline.original: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER and SHERRI DAY

docs.lead_paragraph: Pacing before a backdrop of glittering Manhattan skyscrapers that made New York City look like Oz, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani delivered a speech on the state of the city last night that was an attempt to both soften his sharp edges and set a political legacy for what will be the first year of the rest of his life. Mr. Giuliani, who spoke without notes for nearly two hours to lawmakers in the ornate City Council chamber, made his most extensive proposals in education, urging an extension of the school week to Saturday and Sunday for tens of thousands of students who need extra help in science and English. [Page B4.]

headline.main: GIULIANI PROPOSES EXTENDING SCHOOL TO 'PATCH' SYSTEM

docs.abstract: New York City Mayor Rudolph Giuliani delivers conciliatory speech on state of the city in his eighth and final year on job; attempts to both soften his sharp edges and set political legacy; addresses City Council chamber packed with political, cultural and business leaders; makes most extensive proposals for education; urges extension of school week to Saturday and Sunday for tens of thousands of students who need extra help; calls for expanding summer school to accommodate 50,000 more students, suspension centers at every school for problem students, immediate construction of 12 schools and libraries in each of 21,000 classrooms for kindergarten through eighth grade; says proposals, including sale of Board of Education headquarters, are aimed at patching up broken system; announces plans to spend $600 million more on low- and middle-income housing in next four years, intensified sweep to track down 26,000 people wanted for felonies and greater efforts to sign up poor for government health insurance in Health Stat, program he created in 2000; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: In ''Testing 1, 2, 3: My Brush With Managed Care'' (letter, Jan. 4), the writer reports needless antibiotic treatment for a sore throat because of a lack of insurance coverage for a rapid strep test. It is true that indiscriminate use of antibiotics assists in creating drug-resistant superbugs. But presumptive antibiotic treatment of a sore throat before the results of a standard 24-hour strep culture is not uniformly accepted management.
docs.abstract: Dr Morris J Schoeneman reply to Jan 4 letter blaming managed care for needless treatment with antibiotics

docs.lead_paragraph: A Roto-Rooter operator collapses and dies while working on a drain. Assumption: a heart attack. A seemingly healthy baby dies in his sleep. Assumption: sudden infant death syndrome. An elderly Kentucky woman known from C.T. scans to have malignant-looking lesions in her brain dies before undergoing exploratory surgery. Assumption: metastatic cancer. A 43-year-old Connecticut man with shortness of breath, a cough, positive skin test for tuberculosis and multiple clots in his lungs dies before a biopsy can be performed. Assumption: tuberculosis. But when autopsies were performed on these people, quite different stories emerged. The Roto-Rooter operator was electrocuted, a finding that may have saved the lives of others using the faulty equipment and that resulted in double-indemnity insurance for his survivors.

headline.main: A Price to Pay as Autopsies Lose Favor

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column cites role of autopsy in helping living learn from dead; notes rate of autopsies in nation's hospitals has been falling for decades, largely because of financial pressures; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: In his State of the State address (front page, Jan. 4), Gov. George E. Pataki took the position that ''people with disabilities should not have to choose between going to work or having health insurance.'' There are 54 million Americans with disabilities. Nearly 70 percent of those of working age are not working; however, the vast majority can work and want to. They need effective training programs, real job opportunities -- and legal assurance that they will not lose their health insurance coverage if they go to work.
docs.abstract: International Center for the Disabled official Daniel B Rosen letter on Jan 4 article on Gov George E Pataki's State of the State speech calls for programs to allow disabled to work
